required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study to Assess the Pharmacokinetics of a Modified-release Tacrolimus Based Immunosuppression Regimen in Stable Kidney Transplant Patients
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 2, Open-Label, Multi-center Study to Assess the Pharmacokinetics, Safety and Tolerability of Tacrolimus in Stable Kidney Transplant Patients Converted From a Prograf® Based Immunosuppression Regimen to a Modified Release (MR) Tacrolimus Based Immunosuppression Regimen

brief_summary.textblock: A study to assess the pharmacokinetics, safety and effectiveness of tacrolimus in stable kidney transplant patients converted from a Prograf® based immunosuppression regimen to a modified release tacrolimus based immunosuppression regimen.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a Phase II open-label, multi-center conversion study in stable, adult kidney transplant recipients to assess the pharmacokinetics, safety and effectiveness of tacrolimus in stable kidney transplant patients converted from a Prograf® based immunosuppression regimen to a modified release tacrolimus based immunosuppression regimen.

primary_outcome.measure: Area Under the Concentration-time Curve From Time 0 to 24 Hours (AUC0-24) for Tacrolimus
primary_outcome.time_frame: For tacrolimus, Days 1 and 7 at 0 (pre-dose), 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 6, 8, 12 (pre-dose), 13, 14, 15, 18, 20, and 24 hours. For tacrolimus MR, Days 14 and 21 pre-dose and 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 15, 18, 20, and 24 hours post-dose.
primary_outcome.description: The area under the concentration-time curve was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR at steady state using the trapezoidal rule.

primary_outcome.time_frame: For tacrolimus, Days 1 and 7 at 0 (pre-dose), 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 6, 8, 12 (pre-dose), 13, 14, 15, 18, 20, and 24 hours. For tacrolimus MR, Days 14 and 21 pre-dose and 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 15, 18, 20, and 24 hours post-dose.
primary_outcome.description: The maximum concentration was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR at steady state, without interpolation.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 7 (tacrolimus) and Days 14 and 21 (tacrolimus MR), 24 hours post-dose.
primary_outcome.description: The trough (minimum) concentration of tacrolimus determined from the tacrolimus whole blood concentration value at the 24-hour time point post- dose, prior to receiving the next dose.

primary_outcome.measure: Time to Maximum Observed Concentration of Tacrolimus (Tmax)
primary_outcome.time_frame: For tacrolimus, Days 1 and 7 at 0 (pre-dose), 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 6, 8, 12 (pre-dose), 13, 14, 15, 18, 20, and 24 hours. For tacrolimus MR, Days 14 and 21 pre-dose and 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 15, 18, 20, and 24 hours post-dose.
primary_outcome.description: The time to reach the maximum concentration of tacrolimus was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR at steady state, without interpolation.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
primary_outcome.description: Patient Survival defined as any participant who did not die by the time of analysis.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
primary_outcome.description: Graft survival was defined as any participant who did not meet the definition of graft loss, where graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant or permanent return to dialysis (for more than 30 days)) or participants death.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ IA. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Serum Creatinine
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (the last day of tacrolimus on Day 7), Day 35 (end of the pharmacokinetic phase) and end of treatment (EOT; the last observed value during treatment, maximum time on study was 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Renal function was assessed using serum creatinine levels over the course of the study.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Creatinine Clearance
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (the last day of tacrolimus on Day 7), Day 35 (end of the pharmacokinetic phase) and end of treatment (EOT; the last observed value during treatment, maximum time on study was 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Renal function was assessed using creatinine clearance levels calculated using the Cockcroft-Gault formula, over the course of the study.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Event for Patient Non Survival
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: For participants who died on study, the median number of days from enrollment to death due to any cause.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Event for Graft Non Survival
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: For participants with graft loss, the median number of days from enrollment to graft loss. Graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant or permanent return to dialysis (for more than 30 days)) or participant death.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: For participants with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection, the median number of days from enrollment to the date of biopsy confirmation. Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ IA. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel.

secondary_outcome.measure: Grade of Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection Episodes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ IA. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel. For participants with more than one biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episode, the worst case grade is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Receiving Anti-lymphocyte Antibody Therapy for Acute Rejection
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Steroid-resistant rejection episodes were treated with anti-lymphocyte antibodies. If a participant had a histologically proven Banff Grade II or III rejection, they could be initiated on anti-lymphocyte antibody treatment per institutional practice. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Multiple Rejection Episodes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: This analysis includes rejection episodes that were either confirmed by biopsy by the clinical site pathologist or were clinically treated.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Clinically Treated Acute Rejection Episodes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: A clinically treated acute rejection episode was any biopsy-confirmed or suspected rejection episode that was treated with immunosuppressive therapy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Chronic Rejection
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Due to the low number of participants with biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episodes, chronic rejection was not analyzed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Treatment Failure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Treatment failure was defined as discontinuation of study drug for any reason. Due to discontinuation of the study by the sponsor, treatment failure was not analyzed.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: The primary reason for graft loss was recorded by the Investigator. Graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant or permanent return to dialysis) or death. GBM = glomerular basement membrane.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Returning to Permanent Dialysis
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Permanent dialysis defined as dialysis for longer than 30 days.

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety as Assessed by Adverse Events, Laboratory Parameters and Vital Signs
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From the first dose of tacrolimus MR formulation through the day of last dose plus 10 days (approximately 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: An adverse event was defined as any reaction, side effect or other untoward medical occurrence, regardless of the relationship to study drug which occurred during the conduct of a clinical study. Clinically significant adverse changes in clinical status, routine laboratory studies or physical examinations were considered adverse events. A serious adverse event was any adverse event occurring at any dose that resulted in any of the following outcomes: Death Life-threatening adverse event Inpatient hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization Persistent or significant disability or incapacity Congenital abnormality or birth defect Important medical event.

arm_group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient is currently receiving Prograf ® based immunosuppressive therapy for kidney transplantation.
- Patient has stable whole blood trough level concentrations of Prograf® and is clinically stable
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient has previously received an organ transplant other than a kidney
- Patient is currently receiving sirolimus immunosuppression therapy.

reference.citation: Alloway R, Steinberg S, Khalil K, Gourishankar S, Miller J, Norman D, Hariharan S, Pirsch J, Matas A, Zaltzman J, Wisemandle K, Fitzsimmons W, First MR. Two years postconversion from a prograf-based regimen to a once-daily tacrolimus extended-release formulation in stable kidney transplant recipients. Transplantation. 2007 Jun 27;83(12):1648-51.

Alloway R, Steinberg S, Khalil K, Gourishankar S, Miller J, Norman D, Hariharan S, Pirsch J, Matas A, Zaltzman J, Wisemandle K, Fitzsimmons W, First MR. Conversion of stable kidney transplant recipients from a twice daily Prograf-based regimen to a once daily modified release tacrolimus-based regimen. Transplant Proc. 2005 Mar;37(2):867-70.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Stable, adult kidney transplant recipients being treated with tacrolimus (Prograf)-based immunosuppressive regimen.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Pharmacokinetic (PK) treatment period was from Day 1 - 35. Participants who completed the PK period were eligible to continue receiving tacrolimus MR in the extended treatment period, from Day 36 up to 60 months.

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

participants_list.participants: One patient who completed the PK period did not enter the extended treatment period.

baseline.population: Pharmacokinetic evaluable set defined as all patients with all five complete pharmacokinetic profiles (two tacrolimus and three tacrolimus MR).

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

Gender
Race/Ethnicity, Customized
Reason for End Stage Renal Disease

outcome.title: Area Under the Concentration-time Curve From Time 0 to 24 Hours (AUC0-24) for Tacrolimus
outcome.description: The area under the concentration-time curve was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR at steady state using the trapezoidal rule.
outcome.time_frame: For tacrolimus, Days 1 and 7 at 0 (pre-dose), 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 6, 8, 12 (pre-dose), 13, 14, 15, 18, 20, and 24 hours. For tacrolimus MR, Days 14 and 21 pre-dose and 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 15, 18, 20, and 24 hours post-dose.
outcome.population: The number of participants analyzed represents the Pharmacokinetic evaluable set, defined as patients with all five complete pharmacokinetic profiles (two tacrolimus and three tacrolimus MR).

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Area Under the Concentration-time Curve From Time 0 to 24 Hours (AUC0-24) for Tacrolimus
measure.description: The area under the concentration-time curve was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR at steady state using the trapezoidal rule.
measure.population: The number of participants analyzed represents the Pharmacokinetic evaluable set, defined as patients with all five complete pharmacokinetic profiles (two tacrolimus and three tacrolimus MR).

analysis.groups_desc: The method of analysis of variance with repeated measures was used for the comparisons of AUC0-24. Exposure at steady state was used for tacrolimus (steady state was defined as days 1 and 7) and for tacrolimus MR (steady state was defined as days 14 and 21). The natural log (ln) was used to transform AUC0-24 prior to analysis and the results were transformed back to the original scale for the presentation of results.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: If the 90% Confidence Interval for the ratio of the natural log-transformed pharmacokinetic parameters fell within an 80% to 125% range, then the exposure between the two formulations was considered to be equivalent.
analysis.estimate_desc: Tacrolimus/tacrolimus MR ratio of natural log transformed means expressed as a percent.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection
outcome.description: Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ IA. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection
measure.description: Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ IA. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel.

outcome.title: Maximum Observed Concentration (Cmax) of Tacrolimus
outcome.description: The maximum concentration was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR at steady state, without interpolation.
outcome.time_frame: For tacrolimus, Days 1 and 7 at 0 (pre-dose), 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 6, 8, 12 (pre-dose), 13, 14, 15, 18, 20, and 24 hours. For tacrolimus MR, Days 14 and 21 pre-dose and 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 15, 18, 20, and 24 hours post-dose.
outcome.population: The number of participants analyzed represents the Pharmacokinetic evaluable set.

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Maximum Observed Concentration (Cmax) of Tacrolimus
measure.description: The maximum concentration was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR at steady state, without interpolation.
measure.population: The number of participants analyzed represents the Pharmacokinetic evaluable set.

analysis.groups_desc: The method of analysis of variance with repeated measures was used for the comparisons of Cmax. Exposure at steady state was used for tacrolimus (steady state was defined as days 1 and 7) and for tacrolimus MR (steady state was defined as days 14 and 21). The natural log (ln) was used to transform Cmax prior to analysis and the results were transformed back to the original scale for the presentation of results.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: If the 90% CI for the ratio of the natural log-transformed pharmacokinetic parameters fell within an 80% to 125% range, then the exposure between the two formulations was considered to be equivalent.
analysis.estimate_desc: Tacrolimus/tacrolimus MR ratio of natural log transformed means expressed as a percent.

outcome.title: Minimum Concentration of Tacrolimus (Cmin)
outcome.description: The trough (minimum) concentration of tacrolimus determined from the tacrolimus whole blood concentration value at the 24-hour time point post- dose, prior to receiving the next dose.
outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 7 (tacrolimus) and Days 14 and 21 (tacrolimus MR), 24 hours post-dose.
outcome.population: The number of participants analyzed represents the trough evaluable set defined as all patients with replicate trough measurements for both tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR.

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.population: The number of participants analyzed represents the trough evaluable set defined as all patients with replicate trough measurements for both tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR.

analysis.groups_desc: The method of analysis of variance with repeated measures was used for the comparisons of Cmin. Exposure at steady state was used for tacrolimus (steady state was defined as days 1 and 7) and for tacrolimus MR (steady state was defined as days 14 and 21). The natural log (ln) was used to transform Cmin prior to analysis and the results were transformed back to the original scale for the presentation of results.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: If the 90% CI for the ratio of the natural log-transformed pharmacokinetic parameters fell within an 80% to 125% range, then the exposure between the two formulations was considered to be equivalent.
analysis.estimate_desc: Tacrolimus/tacrolimus MR ratio of natural log transformed means expressed as a percent.

outcome.description: Patient Survival defined as any participant who did not die by the time of analysis.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
outcome.population: Modified full analysis set, defined as all patients who took at least one dose of tacrolimus MR during the extension portion of the study.

outcome.population: Modified safety analysis set defined as all patients who took at least 1 dose of tacrolimus and at least one dose of tacrolimus MR during the pharmacokinetic portion of the study. “N” indicates the number of participants with available data at each time point.”

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Time to Event for Patient Non Survival
measure.description: For participants who died on study, the median number of days from enrollment to death due to any cause.
measure.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set who died on study.

outcome.title: Time to Event for Graft Non Survival
outcome.description: For participants with graft loss, the median number of days from enrollment to graft loss. Graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant or permanent return to dialysis (for more than 30 days)) or participant death.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
outcome.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with graft loss.

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Time to Event for Graft Non Survival
measure.description: For participants with graft loss, the median number of days from enrollment to graft loss. Graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant or permanent return to dialysis (for more than 30 days)) or participant death.
measure.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with graft loss.

outcome.title: Time to First Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection
outcome.description: For participants with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection, the median number of days from enrollment to the date of biopsy confirmation. Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ IA. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
outcome.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection.

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Time to First Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection
measure.description: For participants with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection, the median number of days from enrollment to the date of biopsy confirmation. Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ IA. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel.
measure.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection.

outcome.title: Grade of Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection Episodes
outcome.description: Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ IA. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel. For participants with more than one biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episode, the worst case grade is reported.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
outcome.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection.

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Grade of Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection Episodes
measure.description: Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ IA. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel. For participants with more than one biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episode, the worst case grade is reported.
measure.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection.

outcome.title: Number of Participants Receiving Anti-lymphocyte Antibody Therapy for Acute Rejection
outcome.description: Steroid-resistant rejection episodes were treated with anti-lymphocyte antibodies. If a participant had a histologically proven Banff Grade II or III rejection, they could be initiated on anti-lymphocyte antibody treatment per institutional practice. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Number of Participants Receiving Anti-lymphocyte Antibody Therapy for Acute Rejection
measure.description: Steroid-resistant rejection episodes were treated with anti-lymphocyte antibodies. If a participant had a histologically proven Banff Grade II or III rejection, they could be initiated on anti-lymphocyte antibody treatment per institutional practice. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria: Borderline: No intimal arteritis present but foci of mild tubulitis; Grade I: Significant interstitial infiltration and foci of moderate to severe tubulitis; Grade II: Mild to severe intimal arteritis; Grade III: Transmural arteritis and/or arterial fibrinoid change and necrosis of medial smooth muscle cells with accompanying lymphocytic infiltrate in vessel.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Multiple Rejection Episodes
outcome.description: This analysis includes rejection episodes that were either confirmed by biopsy by the clinical site pathologist or were clinically treated.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Multiple Rejection Episodes
measure.description: This analysis includes rejection episodes that were either confirmed by biopsy by the clinical site pathologist or were clinically treated.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Clinically Treated Acute Rejection Episodes
outcome.description: A clinically treated acute rejection episode was any biopsy-confirmed or suspected rejection episode that was treated with immunosuppressive therapy.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Clinically Treated Acute Rejection Episodes
measure.description: A clinically treated acute rejection episode was any biopsy-confirmed or suspected rejection episode that was treated with immunosuppressive therapy.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Chronic Rejection
outcome.description: Due to the low number of participants with biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episodes, chronic rejection was not analyzed.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Chronic Rejection
measure.description: Due to the low number of participants with biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episodes, chronic rejection was not analyzed.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Treatment Failure
outcome.description: Treatment failure was defined as discontinuation of study drug for any reason. Due to discontinuation of the study by the sponsor, treatment failure was not analyzed.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Treatment Failure
measure.description: Treatment failure was defined as discontinuation of study drug for any reason. Due to discontinuation of the study by the sponsor, treatment failure was not analyzed.

outcome.title: Primary Reason for Graft Loss
outcome.description: The primary reason for graft loss was recorded by the Investigator. Graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant or permanent return to dialysis) or death. GBM = glomerular basement membrane.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
outcome.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with graft loss.

group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. outcome.title: Number of Participants Returning to Permanent Dialysis
outcome.description: Permanent dialysis defined as dialysis for longer than 30 days.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. measure.title: Number of Participants Returning to Permanent Dialysis
measure.description: Permanent dialysis defined as dialysis for longer than 30 days.

outcome.title: Safety as Assessed by Adverse Events, Laboratory Parameters and Vital Signs
outcome.description: An adverse event was defined as any reaction, side effect or other untoward medical occurrence, regardless of the relationship to study drug which occurred during the conduct of a clinical study. Clinically significant adverse changes in clinical status, routine laboratory studies or physical examinations were considered adverse events. A serious adverse event was any adverse event occurring at any dose that resulted in any of the following outcomes: Death Life-threatening adverse event Inpatient hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization Persistent or significant disability or incapacity Congenital abnormality or birth defect Important medical event.
outcome.time_frame: From the first dose of tacrolimus MR formulation through the day of last dose plus 10 days (approximately 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus Modified Release
group.description: Participants were enrolled into the study on their stable twice-daily (bid) dose of tacrolimus on Day 1 and continued to receive a stable bid dose of tacrolimus through Day 7. Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain tacrolimus trough concentrations within the target range of 5 to 15 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Safety as Assessed by Adverse Events, Laboratory Parameters and Vital Signs
measure.description: An adverse event was defined as any reaction, side effect or other untoward medical occurrence, regardless of the relationship to study drug which occurred during the conduct of a clinical study. Clinically significant adverse changes in clinical status, routine laboratory studies or physical examinations were considered adverse events. A serious adverse event was any adverse event occurring at any dose that resulted in any of the following outcomes: Death Life-threatening adverse event Inpatient hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization Persistent or significant disability or incapacity Congenital abnormality or birth defect Important medical event.

class.title: Adverse Event leading to dose changes

reported_events.time_frame: From the first dose of tacrolimus MR formulation through the day of last dose plus 10 days (approximately 60 months).
reported_events.desc: Adverse events are reported for the modified safety analysis set defined as all patients who took at least 1 dose of tacrolimus MR during the pharmacokinetic period of the study.

Participants then converted to Tacrolimus Modified Release (MR), administered once daily at an equivalent dose to the patient's previous stable total daily dose of tacrolimus. Participants who completed the 4-week pharmacokinetic treatment period with tacrolimus MR could continue receiving tacrolimus MR as part of the extended treatment period of the study. category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Institute and/or Principal Investigator may publish trial data generated at their specific study site after Sponsor publication of the multi-center data or until 18 months have elapsed following study completion. Sponsor must receive a site’s manuscript at least 30 days prior to publication to ensure that no confidential information of Sponsor is included in the document.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Company makes no warranties or representations of any kind as to the posting, expressed or implied, including warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose, and shall not be liable for any damages.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Vice President, Therapeutic Area Head, Transplantation
